description: From Middle English drit (“excrement”), from Old Norse drit (“excrement”), from Proto-Germanic *dritą, *dritō (“excrement”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰreyd-, *treydʰ- (“to have diarrhea”). Cognate with Norwegian dritt (“excrement”), Icelandic drit (“bird excrement”), Dutch drijten (“to defecate”), drits (“dirt, mud, filth”) and drijt, dreet (“excrement”), Low German drieten (“to defecate”), Driet (“shit”), regional German Driss (“shit”), Old English ġedrītan (“to defecate”), Albanian ndyrë (“dirty, filthy”).

entries.meaning: A stain or spot (on clothes etc); any foreign substance that worsens appearance.
Previously unknown facts, or the invented "facts", about a person.
examples: The reporter uncovered the dirt on the businessman by going undercover.
honours  […]  thrown away upon dirt and infamy

entries.meaning: (mining) In placer mining, earth, gravel, etc., before washing.

examples: I'm one of Charlie's Angels too, but I'm the one with the dirty face.

verbs.description: dirt (third-person singular simple present dirts, present participle dirting, simple past and past participle dirted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To make foul or filthy; soil; befoul; dirty
